This is because the argument attacks the character or motives of those who disagree rather than addressing the actual issue of military spending. An example of this fallacy in action could be: "You can't possibly understand the importance of military spending if you've never served in the armed forces yourself."

An example of this fallacy in action could be: "Everyone is on board with increasing defense budgets, so why should we be the only ones left behind?"

This is because the argument relies on stirring up emotions (fear for the safety of troops) rather than providing logical reasons for not cutting military funding. - Explanation: This tweet implies that the majority opinion determines what is right, rather than considering the actual evidence or reasons behind the decision.
